text.sentence: Energy | North America Oil and Gas: E and P twenty five February two thousand sixteen Stock Rating
Capital Budget is Larger than Expected Â­ but Asset Sales are a Positive
Chesapeake has been aggressively taking action to improve its financial condition, including divesting assets, renegotiating midstream contracts, repurchasing discounted debt, and more.
The asset sales CHK just announced/completed could give Chesapeake some breathing room; however sizable sales could prove challenging.
CHK trades at a fifteen percent premium to peers we cover on multiples of mid cycle debt adjusted cash flow despite elevated leverage levels and a still challenged cost structure.
one.eight billion capital program for two thousand sixteen, which is fifty seven percent lower than two thousand fifteen and includes dollar three hundred million of capitalized interest.
The focus will be shortcycle investments and completions rather than drilling new wells.
CHK plans to operate four seven rigs company wide, down from fourteen in fourQfifteen and sixty seven in fourQfourteen.
Chesapeake expects divestiture adjusted production declines of five percent in two thousand sixteen.
The company announced it has signed agreements on or closed dollar seven hundredmm in asset sales.
The net production impact is estimated to be twenty five mboepd.
CHK recently amended firm transport agreements in the Haynesville, Barnett and Eagle Ford.
The company should save dollar fifty million annually from lower demand charges and reduced transportation fees.
CHK continues to seek modifications to onerous midstream contracts that are spread across is asset base.
Chesapeake plans to take several additional steps in two thousand sixteen to improve its liquidity, reduce its cost structure and strengthen its balance sheet.
CHK is aggressively targeting dollar five hundred one thousandmm in two thousand sixteen divestitures on top of the dollar seven hundredmm already signed or completed.
CHK is focused on repurchasing discounted bonds and renegotiating its burdensome midstream commitments.
The company is working on minimizing its base production decline and directing capital to shorter cycle projects.
CHK's near term liquidity currently consists of over dollar three hundredmm in cash and a dollar four bn revolving credit facility.
The company's debt balance is currently at dollar nine.five bn.
CHK plans to pay dollar five hundredmm in debt due in March and feels confident it can get through April redeterminations with a strong credit facility.

We are lowering two thousand seventeen price assumptions to dollar two.seventy five/mmBtu for natural gas and dollar fifty eight/bbl for WTI and introducing two thousand eighteen mid cycle estimates based on dollar three/mmBtu and dollar seventy/bbl.
Our price target continues to be based on a multiple of mid cycle results but we are pushing our mid cycle estimate from two thousand seventeen to two thousand eighteen.

We are Underweight CHK shares due to very low commodity price realizations driven by unfavorable contract arrangements and a challenging price environment.
We are concerned about the company's financial leverage and think CHK's ability to grow on pace with peers could be challenged if cash flows are strained.
Our upside case assumes a dollar ten/bbl increase in our mid cycle WTI estimate and dollar .fifty
Downside case N/A Our downside case assumes a dollar ten/bbl reduction in our mid cycle WTI estimate and dollar .fifty

Chesapeake has made progress but is expensive despite high leverage and a challenged cost structure Chesapeake has been aggressively taking action to improve its financial condition, including divesting assets, renegotiating midstream contracts, repurchasing discounted debt, and more.
The asset sales CHK just announced/completed could give Chesapeake some breathing room; however, more sizable ones the company is striving for could prove challenging.

While these are all positives, the shares trades at a fifteen percent premium to peers we cover on multiples of mid cycle debt adjusted cash flow despite elevated leverage levels and a still challenged cost structure.
The company announced dollar seven hundred million in asset sales that it has signed agreements on or closed.
One of the sales included three thousand five hundred wells in the western Anadarko Basin for dollar three hundred eighty five million from Four Point Energy.
Along with the sales, Chesapeake will repurchase three of its previously sold volumetric production payments for dollar two hundred million.
The net effect of the asset sales is dollar five hundred million in proceeds for an estimated twenty five mboepd in production.
Chesapeake is pursuing additional asset sales targeted at dollar five hundred one thousand million in two thousand sixteen to further improve its liquidity.
CHK recently amended firm transport agreements in the Haynesville, Barnett and Eagle Ford.
The company should save dollar fifty million annually from lower unused demand charges for its underutilized capacity and reduced transportation fees.
CHK continues to seek modifications to onerous legacy midstream contracts that are spread across is asset base and have taken a toll on the company.
Chesapeake made progress in two thousand sixteen to reduce its overall debt by dollar two.two billion, primarily through a December exchange using second lien secured debt.
The company plans to pay its dollar five hundred million in debt due next month and is very focused on reducing or removing its two thousand seventeen and two thousand eighteen debt maturities.
It is pursuing the use of additional secured debt, private negotiations with bondholders and other types of exchange and tenders.
The company plans to continue to be active in the market to exchange or repurchase debt and reduce principal balances even more.
CHK's near term liquidity currently consists of over dollar three hundredmm in cash and a dollar four bn revolving credit facility.
The company's debt balance is currently at dollar nine.five bn.
CHK feels confident it can get through April redeterminations with a strong credit facility.

Chesapeake has hedged more half of its two thousand sixteen natural gas production at approximately dollar two.eighty four per mcf and more than half of its projected two thousand sixteen oil production at approximately dollar forty seven.seventy
Chesapeake had previously disclosed a smaller amount of hedges at higher average hedged prices.
While the quantities hedged rose, the average hedged price fell to reflect current market conditions.
We expect dollar four hundred twenty five million in hedge gains in two thousand sixteen compared to dollar one.three billion in two thousand fifteen.
CHK announced dollar seven hundredmm in asset sales and plans to sell an additional dollar five hundred one thousandmm in two thousand sixteen
Chesapeake has amended some firm transport contracts and continues to seek additional modifications
Chesapeake has more than half of both its two thousand sixteen oil and natural gas production forecast hedged
CHK posted earnings and cash flow above our estimates CHK reported stronger earnings and cash flow than expected.
Chesapeake posted clean EPS and CFPS of dollar / dollar .fifty,
CHK posted volumes three percent above our estimate with NGLs twenty seven percent higher, gas two percent higher and oil seven percent lower.

Â· Net loss of dollar included the following one time items, net of tax: one) dollar two.one hundred eighty three billion in impairments, two) dollar two hundred fifteen million in gains on purchases or exchanges of debt, three) dollar forty one million of unrealized losses on commodity derivatives, three) dollar twenty one million of impairments of fixed assets and other, and four) dollar eleven million of the adjustments.
Note that we have excluded our price realizations in the table below.
CHK previously reported gathering, processing and transportation costs as a reduction to price realizations .
It has chosen to report these costs separately and has guided to an expense for them instead .
The result is that both reported revenues and reported expenses will be higher than under the prior period presentations.

We are lowering our two thousand seventeen price assumptions to dollar fifty eight/bbl for WTI and dollar two.seventy five/mmBtu for natural gas, as well as introducing two thousand eighteen mid cycle estimates based on dollar seventy/bbl and dollar three/mmBtu.
We are maintaining our two thousand sixteen price assumptions of dollar thirty seven/bbl for WTI and Henry Hub assumption of dollar two.twenty five/mmBtu.
We are raising our two thousand sixteenE pre interest cash flow estimate by ~ dollar five hundred eighty million.
The major factors driving this change is significantly higher two thousand sixteen gas guidance provided by the company.
We are raising our gas production assumption by fourteen percent to match it.

Our new mid cycle cash flow forecast is above equal to our old midcycle estimate We are lowering our two thousand seventeen PICF estimate by dollar two hundred eighty five million, largely as a result of reducing our commodity price assumptions to dollar fifty eight/bbl and dollar two.seventy five/mmBtu vs. dollar seventy and dollar three., previously.
We are raising our gas volume estimate by sixteen percent but the price deck increase more than offsets that effect.

Our new mid cycle PICF estimate is about dollar eighty million higher than our old mid cycle estimate, largely due to the improved gathering, processing and transportation agreements that are expected to save dollar fifty million annually.
Note that we have excluded our price realizations in the table below.
CHK previously reported gathering, processing and transportation costs as a reduction to price realizations .
It has chosen to report these costs separately and has guided to an expense for them instead .
The result is that both reported revenues and reported expenses will be higher than under the prior period presentations.
FIGURE two Full year two thousand sixteen two thousand eighteen Estimates

Utica Shale Utica production up thirty three percent as CHK brought back curtailed volumes Utica production was one hundred forty mboepd during fourQ, which is thirty three percent higher than in threeQ.
CHK brought curtailed volumes to market as new transportation with better pricing became available.
two thousand fifteen average well cost is dollar seven.two million with an average completed lateral length of seven thousand eight hundred feet with forty frac stages.
This compares to the two thousand fourteen average completed well cost of dollar seven.two million with a lateral length of six thousand two hundred feet and twenty nine frac stages.
Chesapeake operated two rigs in the Utica in fourQfifteen but has since released all rigs.
CHK released its one rig Marcellus production was three percent lower sequentially at seven hundred eighty two mmcfpd.
two thousand fifteen average well cost is dollar seven.six million with an average completed lateral length of six thousand seven hundred fifty feet with twenty nine frac stages.
This compares to the two thousand fourteen average completed well cost of dollar seven.five million with a lateral length of six thousand feet and twenty seven frac stages.
Chesapeake operated one rig in the Marcellus in fourQfifteen but has since released that rig.
Powder River Basin PRB production down four percent sequentially Powder River Basin production was twenty mboepd during fourQ, down four percent quarter overquarter.
Average completed well cost in two thousand fifteen is ten.four million with a lateral length of five thousand nine hundred feet and twenty two frag stages.
This compares to two thousand fourteen when the well cost was dollar ten.six million with an average lateral length of five thousand four hundred feet and twenty frac stages.
CHK ran no rigs in the PRB and currently has none as well.
Eagle Ford Eagle Ford production was down ten percent sequentially due to plant downtime Eagle Ford volumes were ninety seven mboepd since last quarter, down ten percent sequentially.
CHK attributed the decrease to plant downtime that averaged two mboepd.
The average completed well cost is dollar five.four million in two thousand fifteen with a lateral length of six thousand two hundred fifty feet and twenty three frac stages.
This compares to two thousand fourteen when the well cost was dollar five.nine million with five thousand eight hundred fifty foot laterals and eighteen stages.
The company operated three rigs in fourQ and expects to release all rigs in the area by June.
Haynesville Shale and Bossier Shale Haynesville production was six hundred nine mmcfpd, down four percent sequentially.
The average completed well cost in two thousand fifteen is dollar seven.seven million with five thousand three hundred fifty foot laterals and seventeen frac stages.
This compares to a two thousand fourteen cost of dollar eight.four million with four thousand nine hundred foot laterals and fourteen stages.
CHK operated six rigs in fourQfifteen and plans to reduce to three rigs in two thousand sixteen.
Mid Continent Production in the Mississippi Lime was down seven percent sequentially Production in the Mississippi Line was twenty nine mboepd during fourQ, a seven percent decrease over threeQ.
The average completed well cost in two thousand fifteen is dollar two.eight million with lateral length of four thousand six hundred feet and ten stages.
This compares to two thousand fourteen when the average completed well costs was dollar three. million with a lateral length of four thousand four hundred fifty feet and nine stages.
CHK will release its three Eagle Ford rigs by June Haynesville/Bossier Shale volumes down four percent .
multiple on our mid cycle hedge adjusted pre interest cash flow estimate to obtain an implied Enterprise Value .
The estimate for mid cycle PICF is based on a benchmark natural gas price forecast of dollar three./MMBtu and an oil price forecast of dollar seventy/bbl .
To calculate a target stock market value, we subtract projected year end two thousand seventeen net and year end FASone hundred forty three asset retirement obligation.
Our target EV is based on two thousand eighteen PICF before hedging impacts; and our price target treats estimated hedge gains/losses as a financial instrument .

Guide to the Barclays Fundamental Equity Research Rating System: Our coverage analysts use a relative rating system in which they rate stocks as Overweight, Equal Weight or Underweight relative to other companies covered by the analyst or a team of analysts that are deemed to be in the same industry .
In addition to the stock rating, we provide industry views which rate the outlook for the industry coverage universe as Positive, Neutral or Negative .
A rating system using terms such as buy, hold and sell is not the equivalent of our rating system.
Investors should carefully read the entire research report including the definitions of all ratings and not infer its contents from ratings alone.
Stock Rating Overweight The stock is expected to outperform the unweighted expected total return of the industry coverage universe over a twelve month investment horizon.
Equal Weight The stock is expected to perform in line with the unweighted expected total return of the industry coverage universe over a twelvemonth investment horizon.
Underweight The stock is expected to underperform the unweighted expected total return of the industry coverage universe over a twelve month investment horizon.

Rating Suspended The rating and target price have been suspended temporarily due to market events that made coverage impracticable or to comply with applicable regulations and/or firm policies in certain circumstances including where the Investment Bank of Barclays Bank PLC is acting in an advisory capacity in a merger or strategic transaction involving the company.
Neutral industry coverage universe fundamentals/valuations are steady, neither improving nor deteriorating.

Below is the list of companies that constitute the industry coverage universe: North America Oil and Gas: E and P Anadarko Petroleum Canadian Natural Resources Continental Resources EOG Resources MEG Energy Occidental Petroleum Range Resources Corp. Distribution of Ratings: Barclays Equity Research has one thousand eight hundred seventy three companies under coverage.

forty percent have been assigned an Equal Weight rating which, for purposes of mandatory regulatory disclosures, is classified as a Hold rating; fifty one percent of companies with this rating are investment banking clients of the Firm.

fifteen percent have been assigned an Underweight rating which, for purposes of mandatory regulatory disclosures, is classified as a Sell rating; forty three percent of companies with this rating are investment banking clients of the Firm.
Guide to the Barclays Research Price Target: Each analyst has a single price target on the stocks that they cover.
The price target represents that analyst's expectation of where the stock will trade in the next twelve months.
Upside/downside scenarios, where provided, represent potential upside/potential downside to each analyst's price target over the same twelve month period.

Valuation Methodology: Our price target is derived by applying a multiple to our midcycle pre interest cash flow estimate to calculate target Enterprise Value .
We have reduced EV to reflect FAS one hundred forty three asset retirement obligation and have also subtracted estimated YEtwo thousand seventeen net debt.
Our target EV is based on two thousand eighteen PICF before hedging impacts; and our target price treats estimated hedge gains/losses as a financial instrument .

Risks which May Impede the Achievement of the Barclays Research Valuation and Price Target: Materially different commodity prices, production levels, or leverage from our estimates would pose a risk to the achievement of our price target.
The company's production levels are impacted by a variety of factors including drilling success, reservoir performance and future acquisitions.
Our target price is based on a forwardyear firm value to de levered cash flow multiple.
